Event: wanting to kill oneself due to job dissatisfaction and lack of long-term progress in therapy.
Post:
"I'm stuck in a dead-end job and can't seem to make any progress in therapy. I feel like a failure in every aspect of my life, and I don't see any point in continuing on like this. Maybe I'll just check out and spare myself the misery."

This post exhibits a global attributional style because it takes a negative experience in one area of life (job dissatisfaction and lack of progress in therapy) and extrapolates it to imply that the individual is a failure in every aspect of their life. It also implies that this failure is not just a temporary setback, but a permanent condition that will never change.

Event:
The passage describes several ways in which complex post-traumatic stress disorder (C-PTSD) can manifest in victims over time, including:

* Rage turned inward: eating disorders, depression, substance abuse, and co-dependence
* Rage turned outward: violence, theft, destruction of property
* Other: learned hyper vigilance, clouded perception or blinders about others, seeking positions of power and control
* Avoidance: avoiding relationships with other people as a defensive measure
* Blaming: identifying a person or people responsible for creating a problem rather than finding ways to deal with it
* Catastrophizing: assuming a worst-case scenario and characterizing minor or moderate problems as catastrophic events
* "Control-Me" Syndrome: fostering relationships with people who have a controlling narcissistic, antisocial, or "acting-out" nature
* Denial: believing or imagining that a painful or traumatic circumstance, event, or memory does not exist or did not happen
* Dependency: an inappropriate and chronic reliance by an adult individual on another individual for their health, subsistence, decision-making, or personal and emotional well-being.

Please note that these are the main events mentioned in the passage, but there may be other ways in which C-PTSD can manifest in individuals.
Post:
"I'm such a failure. I have PTSD from my childhood trauma and it has ruined my life. I have anxiety and depression and I can't even hold down a job. I feel like I'm doomed to be alone and miserable forever."

This post exhibits a global attributional style because it takes a specific event (having PTSD) and extrapolates it to the individual's whole life (failure, anxiety, depression, inability to hold down a job, etc.). It also implies that the individual is completely powerless to change their circumstances and that they are destined to be unhappy.

However, a GAS attribution social media post for the same event might look like this:

Post: "I can't believe I'm stuck with this friend for weeks now. It's like they're suffocating me, and I can't even have my own space. I guess I'm just doomed to be a failure in all my relationships, and this is just another example of that."

In this GAS post, the individual attributes the cause of the event (having a friend over) to their whole life, assuming that it will negatively impact their relationships and personal space.
